title: 104_s2151
content: The Act states that amendments refer to title 38, United States Code. It is titled the Department Of Veterans Affairs Employment Reduction Assistance Act of 1996. Definitions include "Department" as the Department of Veterans Affairs and "employee" as defined by section 2105 of title 5, United States Code. The Department Of Veterans Affairs Employment Reduction Assistance Act of 1996 defines a period of at least 12 months for eligibility, excluding reemployed annuitants, employees with disabilities eligible for disability retirement, employees with specific notice of separation for misconduct or performance, and employees who accepted voluntary separation incentives. The Department Of Veterans Affairs Employment Reduction Assistance Act of 1996 outlines eligibility criteria for a voluntary separation incentive payment, excluding certain employees such as those who have previously received such a payment or are covered by statutory reemployment rights. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. The Department of Veterans Affairs can submit a plan to the Office of Management and Budget for voluntary separation incentives to reduce the number of employees for efficiency or budget reasons. The plan must detail the intended employment reductions and how they will improve operations or meet budget/staffing needs. It should also include a timeframe for incentive payments and coverage for eligible employees. The Department of Veterans Affairs can submit a plan to the Office of Management and Budget for voluntary separation incentives targeting specific positions based on various factors. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will approve or modify the plan, including the timeframe for incentive payments and coverage criteria. Sec. 4 outlines the requirements for employees to receive voluntary separation incentive payments, including the conditions for separation and the lump sum payment amount based on specific criteria. Employees eligible for voluntary separation incentive payments will receive a lump sum based on specific criteria, with amounts ranging from $25,000 to $10,000 depending on the fiscal year of separation. These payments are not considered for other government benefits or severance pay calculations under section 5595 of title 5, except for unemployment compensation funded with Federal funds. Employees who receive voluntary separation incentive payments must repay the full amount if they accept government employment within 5 years. The repayment can be waived by the Director of the Office of Personnel Management for certain agencies. Employees who receive voluntary separation incentive payments must repay the full amount if they accept government employment within 5 years. Repayment can be waived by the head of the agency, entity, or Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts if the individual has unique abilities and is the only qualified applicant available for the position. Employment includes any length or type of appointment, excluding uncompensated employment. Employees who receive voluntary separation incentive payments must repay the full amount if they accept government employment within 5 years. Repayment can be waived if the individual has unique abilities and is the only qualified applicant available for the position. Employment includes any type of appointment, excluding uncompensated employment. Additionally, the Department must contribute 15 percent of the final basic pay of employees covered under specific chapters of title 5 to the civil service retirement and disability fund. The Act defines "final basic pay" as the total basic pay for a year of service based on the employee's final rate of pay. It also states that one full-time equivalent position in the Department will be reduced for each employee who receives a voluntary separation incentive payment. The Office of Management and Budget will oversee this process to ensure compliance. The Department must ensure compliance with the requirements of this section. The President can waive subsection (a) in cases of war, national emergency, or extraordinary emergencies. The Department must report quarterly to the Office of Personnel Management on the number of employees receiving voluntary separation incentives, the average amount paid, and the average grade or pay level of these employees. The Office of Personnel Management must report annually to Congress on voluntary separation incentives, including the number of employees receiving incentives, average amount, grade/pay level, and waivers granted. The Office of Personnel Management must report annually to Congress on voluntary separation incentives, including employee positions filled, grade/pay level, and waivers granted. Amendments are made to sections regarding voluntary participation in reductions in force and continued health insurance coverage. Sec. 11. Regulations.--The Director of the Office of Personnel Management may prescribe regulations to administer this Act. Sec. 12. Limitation; Savings Clause.--No voluntary separation incentive may be paid after September 30, 2000, and this Act supplements the authority of the Secretary of Veterans Affairs.
